text:
`df = DataFrame(a = range(DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01), today(), step = Dates.DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01)));`
`d_lower = DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01);`
`d_upper = DateTime(2020, 12, 30, 15, 59, 59);`
`filter(:a => (a -> (a >= d_lower) && (a < d_upper)), df)`

elements.text: df = DataFrame(a = range(DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01), today(), step = Dates.DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01)));

text: Check out the docs for `range`. `step` isnt doing what you think it is

elements.text: isnt doing what you think it is

text: you probably want something like `step = Dates.Hour(1)`, at least for this dummy data

elements.text: , at least for this dummy data

text: Ok will do it certainly looks strange how I set it up. I was thinking of just leaving 1 but not sure if that would step second to second or by hour

text:
this works

```julia> df = DataFrame(a = range(DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01), DateTime(today()), step = Dates.Hour(1)));```

elements.text: julia> df = DataFrame(a = range(DateTime(2020, 12, 1, 09, 30, 01), DateTime(today()), step = Dates.Hour(1)));
